item.title: Are flexible screens the future of smartphones?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: LG announced on Monday, October 7, 2013, that it will start mass-producing a flexible, curved smartphone screen. Its first devices to use the new 6-inch OLED screens will be available next year.

item.title: SKARP
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: Making hard work in the kitchen a thing of the past, this smart kitchen integrates new technologies and innovative design. Appliances will communicate with each other and hologramed celebrity chefs will help with the cooking.

item.title: Nike FuelBand
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: Nike's newest product, the Nike Plus FuelBand, is displayed during a product release announcement on Thursday, Jan. 19, 2012 in New York. The wristband provides an athletic measurement of daily physical movement in time, calories and steps that integrates with the iphone and social media networks for sharing. (AP Photo/Bebeto Matthews)

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Self-driving cars of the future can be fooled by fake signals
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For regulatory purposes, artificial is, hopefully, the easy bit. It can simply mean not occurring in nature or not occurring in the same form in nature. Here, the alternative given after the or allows for the possible future use of modified biological materials. Fortunately for would-be regulators, though, the philosophical arguments might be sidestepped, at least for a while. Lets take a step back.

Defining the terms: artificial and intelligence

From a philosophical perspective, intelligence is a vast minefield, especially if treated as including one or more of consciousness, thought, free will and mind. Although traceable back to at least Aristotles time, profound arguments on these Big Four concepts still swirl around us. [caption id="attachment_7" align="alignleft" width="200"] State of AI in 2015[/caption] In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers. Fortunately for would-be regulators, though, the philosophical arguments might be sidestepped, at least for a while. Lets take a step back and ask what a regulators immediate interest is here? Logically, then, it is the way that the majority of AI scientists and engineers treat intelligence that is of most immediate concern. In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers.

Intelligence and the AI community

Until the mid 2000s, there was a tendency in the AI community to contrast artificial intelligence with human intelligence, an action that merely passed the buck to psychologists. In November 2007 an AI pioneer at Stanford University, addressed this issue:
The problem is that we cannot yet characterize in general what kinds of computational procedures we want to call intelligent. John MCarthy
This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other AI. Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model (but a recently proposed variant called reflective AIXI may change that). [caption id="attachment_257" align="alignnone" width="702"] Smart boats and yatches are already here. What does it take to acquire one?[/caption] First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints. One constraint, often emphasised by Hutter, is that AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of time and space limitations. Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence.

Intelligence measures an agents ability to achieve goals in a wide range of environments.

From a consumer perspective, this is ultimately all a question of drawing the line between a system defined as displaying actual AI, as opposed to being just another programmable box. If we can jump all the hurdles, there will be no time for quiet satisfaction. Even without the Big Four, increasingly capable and ubiquitous AI systems will have a huge effect on society over the coming decades, not least for the future of employment. This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other intelligence-related concepts such as learning, planning and problem solving. [caption id="attachment_456" align="alignnone" width="702"] How would you identify an Android?[/caption]

The future of AI

First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints.
  • AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of limitations.
  • Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model.
  • Regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible.
  • May cut across any definition based on general intelligence.
  • Other intelligence-related concepts such as problem solving.
Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence. But if the Big Four do ever (seem to) show up in AI systems, we can safely say that well need not just a yacht of philosophers, but an entire regatta.

item.title: Apples mobile ad blocking will hasten the death of online advertising
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For regulatory purposes, artificial is, hopefully, the easy bit. It can simply mean not occurring in nature or not occurring in the same form in nature. Here, the alternative given after the or allows for the possible future use of modified biological materials. <h2>Defining the terms: artificial and intelligence</h2> From a philosophical perspective, intelligence is a vast minefield, especially if treated as including one or more of consciousness, thought, free will and mind. Although traceable back to at least Aristotles time, profound arguments on these Big Four concepts still swirl around us.
<a href="http://theme-sphere.com/smart-mag/demos/tech/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/09/the-laptop.jpg"><img class="wp-image-7 size-medium" src="http://theme-sphere.com/smart-mag/demos/tech/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/09/the-laptop-200x300.jpg" alt="" width="200" height="300" /></a> State of AI in 2015
In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, <em>Paul Churchland</em> and David Chalmers.
Fortunately for would-be regulators, though, the philosophical arguments might be sidestepped, at least for a while. Lets take a step back and ask what a regulators immediate interest is here?
Logically, then, it is the way that the majority of AI scientists and engineers treat intelligence that is of most immediate concern.
In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, <a href="#">convened a summit</a> on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers. <h2>Intelligence and the AI community</h2> Until the mid 2000s, there was a tendency in the AI community to contrast artificial intelligence with human intelligence, an action that merely passed the buck to psychologists.
In November 2007 an AI pioneer at Stanford University, addressed this issue: <blockquote class="modern-quote full">The problem is that we cannot yet characterize in general what kinds of computational procedures we want to call intelligent.
<cite>John MCarthy</cite></blockquote> This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other AI.
Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model (but a recently proposed variant called <a href="https://intelligence.org/files/ReflectiveSolomonoffAIXI.pdf">reflective AIXI</a> may change that).
<a href="http://theme-sphere.com/smart-mag/demos/tech/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/09/94.jpg"><img class="wp-image-257 size-large" src="http://theme-sphere.com/smart-mag/demos/tech/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/09/94-1024x679.jpeg" alt="" width="702" height="465" /></a> Smart boats and yatches are already here. What does it take to acquire one?
First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints. One constraint, often emphasised by Hutter, is that AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of time and space limitations.
Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence. <h4>Intelligence measures an agents ability to achieve goals in a wide range of environments.</h4> From a consumer perspective, this is ultimately all a question of drawing the line between a system defined as displaying actual AI, as opposed to being just another programmable box.
If we can jump all the hurdles, there will be no time for quiet satisfaction. Even without the Big Four, increasingly capable and ubiquitous AI systems will have a huge effect on society over the coming decades, not least for <a href="http://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/downloads/academic/The_Future_of_Employment.pdf">the future of employment</a>.

First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints.

But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence. But if the Big Four do ever (seem to) show up in AI systems, we can safely say that well need not just a yacht of philosophers, but an entire regatta.

In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers.

Intelligence and the AI community

Until the mid 2000s, there was a tendency in the AI community to contrast artificial intelligence with human intelligence, an action that merely passed the buck to psychologists. In November 2007 an AI pioneer at Stanford University, addressed this issue:
The problem is that we cannot yet characterize in general what kinds of computational procedures we want to call intelligent. John MCarthy
This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other AI. Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model (but a recently proposed variant called reflective AIXI may change that). [caption id="attachment_257" align="alignnone" width="702"] Smart boats and yatches are already here. What does it take to acquire one?[/caption] First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints. One constraint, often emphasised by Hutter, is that AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of time and space limitations. Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence.

Intelligence measures an agents ability to achieve goals in a wide range of environments.

From a consumer perspective, this is ultimately all a question of drawing the line between a system defined as displaying actual AI, as opposed to being just another programmable box.   • Other intelligence-related concepts such as problem solving.
Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence. But if the Big Four do ever (seem to) show up in AI systems, we can safely say that well need not just a yacht of philosophers, but an entire regatta.

[caption id="attachment_7" align="alignleft" width="200"] State of AI in 2015[/caption] In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers. Fortunately for would-be regulators, though, the philosophical arguments might be sidestepped, at least for a while. Lets take a step back and ask what a regulators immediate interest is here? Logically, then, it is the way that the majority of AI scientists and engineers treat intelligence that is of most immediate concern. In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers.

Intelligence and the AI community

Until the mid 2000s, there was a tendency in the AI community to contrast artificial intelligence with human intelligence, an action that merely passed the buck to psychologists. In November 2007 an AI pioneer at Stanford University, addressed this issue:
The problem is that we cannot yet characterize in general what kinds of computational procedures we want to call intelligent. John MCarthy
This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other AI. Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model (but a recently proposed variant called reflective AIXI may change that). [caption id="attachment_257" align="alignnone" width="702"] Smart boats and yatches are already here. What does it take to acquire one?[/caption] First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints. One constraint, often emphasised by Hutter, is that AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of time and space limitations. Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence.

Intelligence measures an agents ability to achieve goals in a wide range of environments.

From a consumer perspective, this is ultimately all a question of drawing the line between a system defined as displaying actual AI, as opposed to being just another programmable box. If we can jump all the hurdles, there will be no time for quiet satisfaction. Even without the Big Four, increasingly capable and ubiquitous AI systems will have a huge effect on society over the coming decades, not least for the future of employment. This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other intelligence-related concepts such as learning, planning and problem solving. [caption id="attachment_456" align="alignnone" width="702"] How would you identify an Android?[/caption]

The future of AI

First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints.
  • AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of limitations.
  • Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model.
  • Regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible.
  • May cut across any definition based on general intelligence.
  • Other intelligence-related concepts such as problem solving.
Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence. But if the Big Four do ever (seem to) show up in AI systems, we can safely say that well need not just a yacht of philosophers, but an entire regatta.

From a consumer perspective, this is ultimately all a question of drawing the line between a system defined as displaying actual AI, as opposed to being just another programmable box. If we can jump all the hurdles, there will be no time for quiet satisfaction. Even without the Big Four, increasingly capable and ubiquitous AI systems will have a huge effect on society over the coming decades, not least for the future of employment. This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other intelligence-related concepts such as learning, planning and problem solving. [caption id="attachment_456" align="alignnone" width="702"] How would you identify an Android?[/caption]

The future of AI

First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints.
  • AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of limitations.
  • Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model.
  • Regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible.
  • May cut across any definition based on general intelligence.
  • Other intelligence-related concepts such as problem solving.
Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence. But if the Big Four do ever (seem to) show up in AI systems, we can safely say that well need not just a yacht of philosophers, but an entire regatta.

From a philosophical perspective, intelligence is a vast minefield, especially if treated as including one or more of consciousness, thought, free will and mind. Although traceable back to at least Aristotles time, profound arguments on these Big Four concepts still swirl around us. [caption id="attachment_7" align="alignleft" width="200"] State of AI in 2015[/caption] In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers. Fortunately for would-be regulators, though, the philosophical arguments might be sidestepped, at least for a while. Lets take a step back and ask what a regulators immediate interest is here? Logically, then, it is the way that the majority of AI scientists and engineers treat intelligence that is of most immediate concern. In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers.

Intelligence and the AI community

Until the mid 2000s, there was a tendency in the AI community to contrast artificial intelligence with human intelligence, an action that merely passed the buck to psychologists. In November 2007 an AI pioneer at Stanford University, addressed this issue:
The problem is that we cannot yet characterize in general what kinds of computational procedures we want to call intelligent. John MCarthy
This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other AI. Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model (but a recently proposed variant called reflective AIXI may change that). [caption id="attachment_257" align="alignnone" width="702"] Smart boats and yatches are already here. What does it take to acquire one?[/caption] First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints. One constraint, often emphasised by Hutter, is that AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of time and space limitations. Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence.

Intelligence measures an agents ability to achieve goals in a wide range of environments.

From a consumer perspective, this is ultimately all a question of drawing the line between a system defined as displaying actual AI, as opposed to being just another programmable box. If we can jump all the hurdles, there will be no time for quiet satisfaction. Even without the Big Four, increasingly capable and ubiquitous AI systems will have a huge effect on society over the coming decades, not least for the future of employment. This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other intelligence-related concepts such as learning, planning and problem solving. [caption id="attachment_456" align="alignnone" width="702"] How would you identify an Android?[/caption]

The future of AI

First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints.
  • AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of limitations.
  • Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model.
  • Regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible.
  • May cut across any definition based on general intelligence.
  • Other intelligence-related concepts such as problem solving.
Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence. But if the Big Four do ever (seem to) show up in AI systems, we can safely say that well need not just a yacht of philosophers, but an entire regatta.

For regulatory purposes, artificial is, hopefully, the easy bit. It can simply mean not occurring in nature or not occurring in the same form in nature. Here, the alternative given after the or allows for the possible future use of modified biological materials.

Defining the terms: artificial and intelligence

From a philosophical perspective, intelligence is a vast minefield, especially if treated as including one or more of consciousness, thought, free will and mind. Although traceable back to at least Aristotles time, profound arguments on these Big Four concepts still swirl around us. [caption id="attachment_7" align="alignleft" width="200"] State of AI in 2015[/caption] In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers. Fortunately for would-be regulators, though, the philosophical arguments might be sidestepped, at least for a while. Lets take a step back and ask what a regulators immediate interest is here? Logically, then, it is the way that the majority of AI scientists and engineers treat intelligence that is of most immediate concern. In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers.

Intelligence and the AI community

Until the mid 2000s, there was a tendency in the AI community to contrast artificial intelligence with human intelligence, an action that merely passed the buck to psychologists. In November 2007 an AI pioneer at Stanford University, addressed this issue:
The problem is that we cannot yet characterize in general what kinds of computational procedures we want to call intelligent. John MCarthy
This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other AI. Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model (but a recently proposed variant called reflective AIXI may change that). [caption id="attachment_257" align="alignnone" width="702"] Smart boats and yatches are already here. What does it take to acquire one?[/caption] First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints. One constraint, often emphasised by Hutter, is that AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of time and space limitations. Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence.

Intelligence measures an agents ability to achieve goals in a wide range of environments.

From a consumer perspective, this is ultimately all a question of drawing the line between a system defined as displaying actual AI, as opposed to being just another programmable box. If we can jump all the hurdles, there will be no time for quiet satisfaction. Even without the Big Four, increasingly capable and ubiquitous AI systems will have a huge effect on society over the coming decades, not least for the future of employment.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
When we talk about artificial intelligence (AI) which we have done lot recently, including the outline of regulation and reliability issues what do we actually mean? In the absence of a regulatory definition at the moment.
AI experts and philosophers are beavering away on the issue about usable definition of AI. It is vital for regulation and governance.

The future of AI

First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints.

But if the Big Four do ever (seem to) show up in AI systems, we can safely say that well need not just a yacht of philosophers, but an entire regatta.

Until the mid 2000s, there was a tendency in the AI community to contrast artificial intelligence with human intelligence, an action that merely passed the buck to psychologists. In November 2007 an AI pioneer at Stanford University, addressed this issue:
The problem is that we cannot yet characterize in general what kinds of computational procedures we want to call intelligent. John MCarthy
This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other AI. Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model (but a recently proposed variant called reflective AIXI may change that). [caption id="attachment_257" align="alignnone" width="702"] Smart boats and yatches are already here. What does it take to acquire one?[/caption] First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints. One constraint, often emphasised by Hutter, is that AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of time and space limitations. Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence.

Intelligence measures an agents ability to achieve goals in a wide range of environments.

From a consumer perspective, this is ultimately all a question of drawing the line between a system defined as displaying actual AI, as opposed to being just another programmable box. If we can jump all the hurdles, there will be no time for quiet satisfaction. Even without the Big Four, increasingly capable and ubiquitous AI systems will have a huge effect on society over the coming decades, not least for the future of employment. This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other intelligence-related concepts such as learning, planning and problem solving. [caption id="attachment_456" align="alignnone" width="702"] How would you identify an Android?[/caption]

The future of AI

First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints.
  • AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of limitations.
  • Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model.
  • Regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible.
  • May cut across any definition based on general intelligence.
  • Other intelligence-related concepts such as problem solving.
Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence. But if the Big Four do ever (seem to) show up in AI systems, we can safely say that well need not just a yacht of philosophers, but an entire regatta.

[caption id="attachment_7" align="alignleft" width="200"] State of AI in 2015[/caption] In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers. Fortunately for would-be regulators, though, the philosophical arguments might be sidestepped, at least for a while. Lets take a step back and ask what a regulators immediate interest is here? Logically, then, it is the way that the majority of AI scientists and engineers treat intelligence that is of most immediate concern. In 2014, seeking to move matters forward, Dmitry Volkov, a Russian technology billionaire, convened a summit on board a yacht of leading philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, Paul Churchland and David Chalmers.

Intelligence and the AI community

Until the mid 2000s, there was a tendency in the AI community to contrast artificial intelligence with human intelligence, an action that merely passed the buck to psychologists. In November 2007 an AI pioneer at Stanford University, addressed this issue:
The problem is that we cannot yet characterize in general what kinds of computational procedures we want to call intelligent. John MCarthy
This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other AI. Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model (but a recently proposed variant called reflective AIXI may change that). [caption id="attachment_257" align="alignnone" width="702"] Smart boats and yatches are already here. What does it take to acquire one?[/caption] First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints. One constraint, often emphasised by Hutter, is that AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of time and space limitations. Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence.

Intelligence measures an agents ability to achieve goals in a wide range of environments.

From a consumer perspective, this is ultimately all a question of drawing the line between a system defined as displaying actual AI, as opposed to being just another programmable box. If we can jump all the hurdles, there will be no time for quiet satisfaction. Even without the Big Four, increasingly capable and ubiquitous AI systems will have a huge effect on society over the coming decades, not least for the future of employment. This informal definition signposts things that a regulator could manage, establishing and applying objective measures of ability (as defined) of an entity in one or more environments (as defined). The core focus on achievement of goals also elegantly covers other intelligence-related concepts such as learning, planning and problem solving. [caption id="attachment_456" align="alignnone" width="702"] How would you identify an Android?[/caption]

The future of AI

First, the informal definition may not be directly usable for regulatory purposes because of AIXIs own underlying constraints.
  • AIXI can only be approximated in a computer because of limitations.
  • Another constraint is that AIXI lacks a self-model.
  • Regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible.
  • May cut across any definition based on general intelligence.
  • Other intelligence-related concepts such as problem solving.
Second, for testing and certification purposes, regulators have to be able to treat intelligence as something divisible into many sub-abilities (such as movement, communication, etc.). But this may cut across any definition based on general intelligence. But if the Big Four do ever (seem to) show up in AI systems, we can safely say that well need not just a yacht of philosophers, but an entire regatta.
